newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Mayne falls on Optus float nerves.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Mayne falls on Optus float nerves.

text.p: Shares in Mayne Nickless Ltd were down over two percent on Friday on uncertainty surrounding the proposed float of Optus Communications Pty Ltd, in which Mayne has a 25 percent stake.
At 11.05 a.m. (0100 GMT), Mayne shares were 23 cents lower at A$8.05 in an overall stronger market and its lowest level since late August.
"It's due to the fact that the Optus float is theoretically delayed, until Optus Vision can come to some sort of settlement with Seven (Network Ltd )," one Melbourne broker said.

On Thursday, the News South Wales Supreme Court handed an interim direction that there would be a hearing to a legal dispute between Optus Vision and Seven over Seven's claims that Optus Vision has breached an earlier agreement. The hearing could delay Optus' float planned for later this year.
Optus Vision is 46.5 percent owned by Optus Communications.
Optus is 24.5 percent owned each by BellSouth Corp of the United States and Cable and Wireless Plc of Britain.
"Their (Mayne's) shares will be affected while all this argy-bargy is going on," the broker said.

Seven owns two percent of Optus Vision and has an option to increase its stake to 15 percent. The television network is also a key sports programming supplier to Optus Vision, a pay television operator.
At 11.15 a.m. (0115 GMT), Seven shares were five cents up at A$3.95. Seven has traded in a band between A$3.66 and A$4.12 over the past month.
